data.title: Famous Birthdays on March 24
data.meta_description: Famous birthdays for the 24th of March. See which celebrities, historical figures, scientists and criminals were born on March 24.
data.text:
Birthdays 1 - 200 of 261

Ferrand, Count of Flanders, son of Sancho I, born in Coimbra, Portugal (d. 1223)

Ernst I, Elector of Saxony (1464-86), born in Meissen (d. 1486)

Georgius Agricola, German mineralogist (De Re Metallica), born in Glauchau, Saxony (d. 1555)

Michiel de Ruyter, Dutch admiral (famous victories during Anglo-Dutch Wars), born in Vlissingen, Spanish Netherlands (d. 1676)

Sophie Amalie of Brunswick-Lüneburg, queen of Denmark and Norway (d. 1685)

José Saenz d'Aguirre, Spanish cardinal, born in Logro, Old Castile (d. 1699)

Arai Hakuseki, Japanese writer and politician (d. 1725)

Georg Philipp Telemann, German late Baroque composer, and multi-instrumentalist, born in Magdeburg, Margraviate of Brandenburg, Holy Roman Empire (d. 1767)

John Harrison

English carpenter and clockmaker who invented the marine chronometer to calculate longitude while at sea, born in Foulby, Yorkshire, England

Jose Francisco de Isla [Francisco de Salazar], Spanish Jesuit preacher and satirist writer, born in Vidanes, Spain (d. 1781)

Carlo Giovanni Testori, Italian violinist, composer, pedagogue, and musicologist (La musica raggionata), born in Vercelli, Kingdom of Venice (d. 1782)

Samuel Ashe, Governor of North Carolina (d. 1813)

1725 Thomas Cushing, American Continental Congressman and acting Governor of Massachusetts (d. 1788)

Gian Francesco de Majo, Italian composer, born in Naples, Kingdom of Naples, House of Habsburg (d. 1770)

Joseph Priestley

English chemist, theologian and author who discovered oxygen and carbonated water, born in Birstall, England

John Antes, American composer and missionary, born in Frederick, Pennsylvania (d. 1811)

Bernard Jumentier, French composer, primarily of sacred music, born in Lèves, France (d. 1829)

Rufus King, American politician and framer of US constitution, born in Scarborough, Massachusetts (d. 1827)

Marcos Portugal [Marcos Antonio da Fonseca Portugal], Portuguese-Brazilian opera, sacred music, and national anthem composer (Portugal - "Hymno Patriótico", 1809; Brazil - "Hino da Independência", 1822), born in Portugal (d. 1830)

Pierre-Louis Hus-Desforges, French composer and cellist, born in Toulon, France (d. 1838)

Orest Kiprensky, Russian painter (d. 1836)

John Corry Wilson Daly, Canadian politician (d. 1878)

Antonio Rosmini-Serbati, Italian philosopher and priest (founder Institute of Charity), born in Rovereto, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1855)

Jacob van Lennep, Dutch poet and novelist (The Adopted Son), born in Amsterdam, Netherlands (d. 1868)

Maria Malibran (née Garcia) Spanish operatic contralto and soprano, born in Paris, France (d. 1836)

Joseph Liouville, French mathematician (discover of transcendental numbers), born in Saint-Omer, France (d. 1882)

1809 Mariano José de Larra, Spanish journalist and romantic writer, born in Madrid, Spain (d. 1837)

Aimé Maillart, French opera composer (Les Dragons de Villars), born in Montpellier, Hérault, France (d. 1871)

Edmond Becquerel, French physicist who studied the solar spectrum, magnetism, electricity and optics (photovoltaic effect), born in Paris, France (d. 1891)

1820 Fanny Crosby, American hymnist known as the "Queen of Gospel Song Writers", born in Brewster, New York (d. 1915)

Rachel Félix, Swiss-born French actress in tragedies (mistress of Napoleon III), born in Mumpf, Switzerland (d. 1858)

1821 [George] Hector Tyndale, American Brevet Major General (Union Army), born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (d. 1880)

George Francis Train, American businessman (d. 1904)

1829 Ignacio Zaragoza, Mexican general (d. 1862)

Robert Hamerling, Austrian poet (d. 1889)

John Wesley Powell, American geologist, explorer (Grand Canyon) and ethnologist, born in Mount Morris, New York (d. 1902)

1834 William Morris, English arts and Crafts designer, craftsman (championed handmade production), poet and socialist, born in Walthamstow, London, England (d. 1896) [1]

Josef Stefan, Slovenian-Austrian physicist (Stefan-Boltzmann law), born in St. Peter, Austria (d. 1893)

Prince Philippe, Count of Flanders and son of Leopold I, born in Royal Castle of Laeken, Belgium (d. 1905)

Augustine Sackett, American inventor of drywall, born in Connecticut (d. 1814) [1]

Honoré Beaugrand, French Canadian journalist, newspaper publisher (La Patrie), and politician (Mayor of Montreal, 1885-87), born in Saint-Joseph-de-Lanoraie, Quebec, Canada East (d. 1906)

Silas Hocking, British novelist and preacher (d. 1935)

Andrew Mellon

American banker (Mellon Bank), industrialist and Secretary of the Treasury (1921-32), born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania

Olive Schreiner, South African writer (Portrait of a South African Woman), born in Wittebergen, Eastern Cape (d. 1920)

Jack McAuliffe, Irish-American boxer and undefeated World Lightweight champion (1886-93), born in Cork, Ireland, United Kingdom (d. 1937)

Leslie Gay, English cricket wicket-keeper (1 Test; Cambridge Uni, Hampshire CCC) and soccer goalkeeper (3 caps; Cambridge Uni), born in Brighton, Sussex (d. 1949)

Harry Houdini

Famous magician and escape artist, born in Budapest, Austria-Hungary

Luigi Einaudi, Italian economist and politician (1st president of Italy 1948-55), born in Carrù, Italy (d. 1961)

Top Naeff, Dutch writer (School Idylls), born in Dordrecht, Netherlands (d. 1953)

James I Wedgwood, British theosophist and bishop (Liberal Catholic Church), born in London (d. 1951)

Gino Marinuzzi, Sr., Italian opera conductor (Wagner; Puccini), and composer (Symphony in A), born in Palermo, Sicily, Kingdom of Italy (d. 1945)

1884 Peter Debye, Dutch-American physical chemist (Nobel Prize for Chemistry 1936 for investigations of dipole moments, X-rays, and light scattering in gases), born in Maastricht, Netherlands (d. 1966)

Charlie Daniels, American swimmer (Olympic gold 220yd, 440yd, 4x50yd freestyle 1904, 100m freestyle 1908), born in Dayton, Ohio (d. 1973)

Athenagoras I, Greek Patriarch of Constantinople (d. 1972)

1886 Edward Weston, American photographer (d. 1958)

Roscoe "Fatty" Arbuckle, American actor (The Bell Boy, Moonshine, Keystone comedies), born in Smith Center, Kansas (d. 1933)

Jameson Thomas, British actor (Piccadilly, Farmer's Wife), born in London, England (d. 1939)

1888 Viktor Kingissepp, Estonian Bolshevik politician (d. 1922)

Albert Hill, English athlete (Olympic gold 800m, 1500m 1920), born in London (d. 1969)

Agnes Macphail, Canadian politician (first women elected to Canada's House of Commons), born in Proton Township, Ontario (d. 1954) [1]

1890 John Rock, American obstetrician and gynecologist who co-developed the 1st birth control pill, born in Marlborough, Massachusetts (d. 1984)

Charley Toorop, Dutch painter (3 Generations), born in Katwijk, Netherlands (d. 1955)

1891 John Knittel, Swiss writer, born in Dharwar, India (d. 1970)

Syd Saylor [Leo Sailor], American silent and sound screen character actor (Arizona Days; The Three Mesquiteers), born in Chicago, Illinois (d. 1962)

Gianna Manzini, Italian writer (Ritratto in piedi), born in Pistoia, Italy (d. 1974)

Charles Eyck, Dutch painter and sculptor (Limburg School), born in Meerssen, Netherlands (d. 1983)

Dorothy Stratton, American coast guard officer (1st woman officer in US Coast Guard, SPARS), born in Brookfield, Missouri (d. 2006)

1898 George Alpert, American railroad executive (New Haven Line), born in Boston, Massachusetts (d. 1988)

(Algeria Junius) "June" Clark, American jazz trumpeter and cornetist, born in Long Branch, New Jersey (d. 1963)

Ub Iwerks, American cartoonist (d. 1971)

Thomas E. Dewey

Governor of NY and Republican presidential candidate (1944, 1948), born in Owosso, Michigan

Adolph Butenandt, German bio-chemist (Nobel Prize for Chemistry 1939 for work on sex hormones), born in Bremerhaven-Wesermünde, Germany (d. 1995)

Pura Santillan-Castrence, Filipino writer and diplomat (d. 2007)

Klavdiya Shulzhenko, Soviet jazz and pop singer ("Let's Smoke"), born in Kharkiv, Russian Empire (now Ukraine) (d. 1984)

Janet Harmon Bragg, American pilot (1st female black aviator to hold a commercial pilot's license), born in Griffin, Georgia (d. 1993) [1]

1907 Lauris Norstad, American general (NATO commander) and CEO (Owens-Corning Fiberglass), born in Minneapolis, Minnesota (d. 1988)

1907 Lydia Chukovskaya, Soviet writer and dissident (Andrei Sakharov Prize for Writer's Civic Courage), born in Helsingfors, Duchy of Finland (d. 1996)

1907 Paul Sauvé, Quebec politician (d. 1960)

Clyde Barrow

American bank robber and outlaw (Bonnie & Clyde), born in Ellis County, Texas

Thomas "Tommy" Trinder, British radio comedian and actor (Save a Little Sunshine, Phoenix), born in Streatham, London, England (d. 1989)

Jacques Chailley, French musicologist and composer, born in Paris (d. 1999)

1910 Richard Conte, American actor (The Godfather, Tony Rome, Hotel), born in Jersey City, New Jersey (d. 1975)

Herman W. "Fritz" Liebert, American rare books scholar and librarian (Yale University), born in New York City (d. 1994)

1911 Jane Beverly Drew, English modernist architect, born in Croydon (d. 1996)

Joseph Barbera

American animator and cartoonist (Hanna-Barbera - Tom and Jerry, Flintstones), born in Manhattan, New York

Dorothy Height

American civil rights and women's rights activist (National Council of Negro Women), born in Richmond, Virginia

Gorgeous George, American professional wrestler (d. 1963)

Donald Hamilton, Swedish-American novelist (d. 2006)

Constantine Andreou, Greek-Brazilian artist (d. 2007)

1917 Ed Furgol, American golfer (US Open 1954), born in New York Mills, NY (d. 1997)

1917 John Kendrew, British molecular biologist, Nobel laureate (d. 1997)

Englebert van Anderlecht, Belgian abstract painter, born in Brussels, Belgium (d. 1961)

John J. Duncan Sr., American politician (Rep-R-TN, 1965-1988), born in Huntsville, Tennessee (d. 1988)

1922 Onna White, Canadian choreographer (d. 2005)

Murray Hamilton, American character actor (Rich Man Poor Man, Anatomy of a Murder), born in Washington, North Carolina (d. 1986)

"Boogie" Bill Webb, American Louisiana blues and R&B guitarist, singer and songwriter ("Bad Dog"), born in Jackson, Mississippi (d. 1990)

1924 Eric Parkin, British classical pianist and champion of British composers, born in Stevenage, England (d. 2020)

1924 Lois Andrews [Lorraine Gourley], American actress (Dixie Dugan, Meet Me After the Show, The Desert Hawk), born in Huntington Park, California (d. 1968)

1925 Puig Aubert, French rugby league footballer (d. 1994)

Martin Walser

German novelist (Marriage in Philippsburg), and dramatist, born in Wasserburg am Bodensee, Germany

Byron Janis [né Yanks], American concert pianist (debut with NBC Symphony Orchestra at age 15), born in McKeesport, Pennsylvania (d. 2024) [1]

Cuan McCarthy, South African cricketer (36 Test wkts for South Africa, 1 career no-ball), born in Pietermaritzburg, Union of South Africa (d. 2000)

Kenneth Nelson, American actor (Henry Aldrich-Aldrich Family), born in Rocky Mount, North Carolina (d. 1993)

Steve McQueen

American actor called "The King of Cool" during the 1960s (The Magnificent Seven, The Great Escape), born in Beech Grove, Indiana

Connie Hines, American actress (Mister Ed), born in Dedham, Massachusetts (d. 2009)

American session bassist (Beach Boys, Sonny & Cher, Simon & Garfunkel), born in Everett, Washington

American-Peruvian tennis player (Australian C'ships, Wimbledon 1959), born in Arequipa, Peru

Canadian scientist, environmentalist and broadcaster (The Nature of Things ), born in Vancouver, British Columbia

David Irving, British historian
